Judul: SPECTROFLUOROMETRIC DETERMINATION OF TRYPTOPHAN IN CANARY (CANARIUM INDICUM L.) PROTEIN HYDROLYSATE
Abstrak:
Canary (Canarium indicum L.) is an indigenous plant of Indonesia, which mainly
grows in the eastern part of Indonesia, especially in the Maluku, North Sulawesi,
and Seram islands. Researches on canary seeds had been done to determine lipid,
protein and amino acids contents. To the best of our knowledge, no scientific reports
have been conducted about tryptophan content in Canarium indicum. Therefore,
this study was conducted to determine the presence and quantitate the aromatic
amino acid (tryptophan) in the canary protein hydrolysate by the
spectrofluorometric method. The protein hydrolysate was prepared by two
hydrolysis methods, enzymatic and alkaline hydrolysis using the purple fruit (adult
fruit) as a starting material. Fluorescence detection is fast and more sensitive and
has less interfering compounds than those of ultraviolet detection (UV). In addition,
tryptophan and tyrosine can be excited at the same wavelength around 280nm, but
they have a different emission wavelength, around 350 nm, and 300 nm
respectively, so tryptophan can be differentiated from tyrosine directly without
using of any reagent by excitation of the sample at 295 nm in order to avoid tyrosine
emission. This method had an exceptional specificity to overcome the presence of
tyrosine, which may be expected to be present in the sample matrix. A proportional
relationship between the increase in fluorescence intensity and tryptophan
concentration in the range 0.5-5 ppm was obtained with a calibration curve
correlation equation y = 6632.3x - 845.42 and correlation coefficient of 0.9997,
while the coefficient of variance in linear regression was 1.29%. The detection limit
and quantification limit obtained were 0.116 ppm and 0.35 ppm respectively. The
recoveries of the accuracy test were obtained in the range of 95-96%. The relative
standard deviation of intra-assay precision tests was obtained in the range of 0.5-
1.8%, while the intermediate precision in the range of 2.18-3.74%. The samples
used in this study were papain, pepsin, and alkaline canary protein hydrolysate.
Tryptophan was detected in all samples (papain, pepsin, and alkaline hydrolysate),
with concentrations 5.58, 5 and 1.47 mg/100mg of protein respectively. The used
fluorimetric method complied the validation requirements and can be used to
analyze tryptophan in samples containing tyrosine without overlapping of spectra
and without the use of any specific reagent.
Kontributor / Dosen Pembimbing: Prof. Dr. Tutus Gusdinar Kartawinata, MS
